How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

Overall I felt like this course was poorly organized and uninformative. I do not feel like I learned much and the professor was extremely disorganized and not engaging. One major weakness of this class was the homework assignments. These were given each week and were on material that hadn't been covered yet. While they were only graded for completion and not accuracy, it was extremely frustrating not having the resources to do the homeworks (the slides for that week weren't even published).
Amazing course and amazing professor.
The course is good.

This class was pretty good. I think that it complements Intro to Reg Affairs (which Makuch also teaches). Some of the topics were redundant, and some of the lectures seemed a bit disorganized, but it all came together at the end.
boring; many materials have already been covered in other courses.

This course had a lot of potential. However, many lectures were redundant (literally the same lecture given twice). Much of the material was a repeat of material learned in other epidemiology classes with little added.
good
I do not recommend taking this course. You don't learn anything and the material covered on the exams are not the same as what was taught in class.

Professor is nice and accommodating to students. However, there were numerous lectures that either weren't completed or weren't even taught, which sometimes made it difficult to follow from week to week. Professor likes to have discussion, but the class size this year was too big for meaningful discussions.

This course has no strengths. It is purely garbage. We learn absolutely nothing, he changes his mind/the assignments constantly, he would only release the homework a day or two prior to the due date, the content on the exams did not at all match what we went over in class. This should be scrapped completely.
great.
Strengths: the contents are helpful
Good overall. Prof Makuch needs to care more about this course.

The course is informative but not challenging which made it kind of boring.
Reducing class size will improve the course.

This course taught me the importance of self-learning and googling.   There was no tutorial sessions to teach how to solve problems or clarifying any doubts regarding lecture materials. I really want to systematically learn about clinical trials, whereas the lecture contents did not connect properly. The information was so scattered, all over the places. The homework was like a "Let us Google it" session, because many things were not mentioned in the lectures at all. I cannot say this is the course I enjoy most this semester.

the strengths: the material is interesting and I really enjoyed having guest lectures from the profession coming in and giving insight about their work.

the weaknesses: the class size is too large to allow for student engagement
Could be more organized, but overall a good course

it might feel a bit like a review of epi stats but you learn a lot in terms of the realities of clinical trials. The professor's really cool and communicates well and the guest speakers are very great

I found the course to be a solid introduction to the planning and analysis of clinical trials. The textbook and readings cover a lot of material and are of high quality. The lecture slides are a bit disorganized.
The course is good.
Teach more substantial stuff more detailly

I had no backgrounds in clinical trials, and I believe this course has offered me a good introduction to clinical trials. I love how flexible this course is, considering that the homeworks are graded on completion and students can correct the answers by themselves. One weakness of this class is that sometimes the homework solutions have mistakes, making the learning process a little confusing, although the mistakes are always corrected several days later. It would be better if the TA or professor could double check the homesork solutions before uploading to canvas.

This course was truly poorly designed and the material that students were assessed on was redundant and irrelevant in the larger scope of implementing skills to conduct clinical trials. The course could be improved with a more attentive TF, and a professor who presents material in a concise and comprehensive manner. The power point materials were virtually useless when reviewed outside of class, so perhaps the class lectures should be recorded.
teaching in the class is too casual and not relevant to the class
Only take this course if you need to for your department requirements/ the regulatory affairs track. Interesting material but poorly taught
The material might  be useful but the class is not well organized and the ppt are sometimes out-dated.
Very useful knowledge and applied things from other biostat courses to clinical trials design.
It would be better if the contents can be more concise and clear.

This course could provide us with an overview of the clinical trial process. But it is not that easy to understand. Also, the professor seems pays less attention to our progress, which is a bit disappointing.
useful class
strength: the homework is highly relevant to the studying material and the exam

The class is a little large, so participation can sometimes feel intimidating. There's not a lot of back and forth or discussion during class sections. However, the content is interesting and presents many practical applications of statistical methods to real-life situations.

Clinical trials is a fascinating subject but one difficult to teach, clearly. 

Strengths: Interesting content; Compelling guest lectures; Clear applicability to work/career
Weaknesses: Inconsistency in statistical approaches between weeks; Some lectures not finished (though material still tested on); Lack of central reference materials; Incoherence between weeks (no building-on).

I think it is an important course but I believe it should be organized better. We spent most of our time repeating same subjects and skipped the others. I really did not like the textbook, the language was hard to understand, most of the time I used the web to get the answers that I wanted to learn. I still believe that I learned a lot about how the trials work and the course changed my biased approach to the pharmaceutical industry a little bit.
I wish the professor could pay more attention to teaching
The professor was unprepared, answer his phones during class, and spent a good portion of the class sharing stories. The lectures were unclear and I am a bit disappointed with the course.

Strengths:
-brought in professionals in the field to answer questions and provide guidance
-homework felt more exploratory: able to make mistakes and learn from them afterwards
-provided answers to homework assignments (to learn from them)

Weaknesses:
-class felt too large, not conducive for discussion 
-the lectures at the end of the semester did not seem as organized as the lectures in the beginning of the semester


Improvement:
-have a class size limit, or make participation to lecture mandatory (because there were a lot of more people during the midterm than during regular class)

This class was absolutely horrible. Prof. Makuch's lectures were incoherent and disorganized. The homework did not help me learn the material. The textbook was dense and boring. There was no rigor in explaining why we used certain statistical tests. I really wanted to learn about clinical trials but I truly do not feel I learned much about that from this class. The class was so poor it made me question if YSPH was worth it.

Strengths: makes you think critically about clinical trials on a broader scale; weekly homework that's graded on completion keeps you on track with the material.

Weaknesses: lectures didn't feel very organized at times (deviation from slides, repetitive lectures)

This course allowed me to practice and expand previous concepts that I learned in statistics classes at YSPH but did little to build on my knowledge base. Attending the lectures was not helpful to me in learning the concepts, doing the homework assignments, or studying for the exams. The powerpoints themselves were helpful in doing the homework and understanding the material.

I think this course has a lot more potential and lectures could have been more lively/ lecture slides prepared more carefully. Lectures were not useful at all and many people stopped showing up after the first few classes. The lecture slides were also clearly recycled from past years with Chinese even left in one one of the lecture slide decks. While it seemed that Professor Makuch did not put a lot of effort into the course, he did seem to genuinely care for students and want us to learn.

Quite honestly, I regret taking this course, despite having seen the poor reviews from previous years. At first, I was hopeful that it would be enriched with real-world experiences and stories from Dr. Makuch's extensive career in the pharmaceutical industry. However, a few stories he told had extremely offensive elements, such as referring to an investigator as "the Egyptian guy with a skin condition" who had been nicknamed "Spot." Dr. Makuch then proceeded to refer to this investigator in the anecdote as "Spot" and described how he had committed fraud. Very disappointing. 

The actual lectures were disorganized eye-sores. They did not always correlate to the textbook. There were two guest lectures as well. The first added zero value to the course but the second by Claude Petit was extremely well-delivered and interesting. 

The work-load was extremely minimal because of the lack of organization. Theoretically, I could have spent 10 hours per week doing the assigned reading, but mid-way through the course, I was so de-motivated by the lack of proper teaching that I couldn't bring myself to keep up with readings. The exams were very easy and did not challenge us to critically think.
exam not graded correctly, the answers were wrong

The content for the class could be better organized. Sometimes the slides contain repetitive information, and the homework and indicated readings are not matched. The homework itself contains repetitive content too, and the answer keys are sometimes wrong, misleading students. I hope there could be a clear outline each class indicating what's going on.
Strengths: the material coveted has useful implications in practical applications

Robert was clearly not very invested in the course this semester. His lectures were disorganized. There were times he would end up answering the phone in the middle of class. He also would tell stories that were irrelevant and then not make it through his slides and would then say that we could read through them on our own.
Wonderful. His presentations and approach are super well balanced.
He is a good instructor. He organized the class well.

Dr. Makuch is a very nice and funny guy. He adds in his own stories to show how what we are learning really is relevant to the real world. He is also very easygoing, like allowing us to take the final exam online. This class seems more math-heavy than Intro-to-Reg affairs, and so possibly working through more problems with us would be beneficial.
He's great. He has a wealth of experience and he relates class topics to real world settings.
Very knowledgable about the field, but lectures were somewhat unorganized and difficult to follow. It was hard to tell what material was import and what was superfluous.
good
Never responded to emails. There was also a question on the midterm that was incorrect and he never gave points back for the exam despite bringing it up to the TF
Nice professor, accommodating.

A nice man who means well but under no circumstances should he be teaching. He is completely scattered, disorganized, content wasn't well thought-out, he brought in guest speakers whenever he didn't feel like teaching, and he was the worst at being available when students needed him.

super helpful and patient;
outstanding in his area;
Nice teacher who is very patient to his students.
Please don't answer two phone calls in the same class. This reflects poorly upon your teaching.
Bad

Very knowledgeable and approachable to questions. Teaches well. But does not ask critically thoughtful questions and did not restrict the class size to be smaller even though that was what was on the course description at the start of the semester.

Professor Makuch taught both Intro to Reg Affairs and Clinical Trials, so we got to hear same stories twice.  Clinical Trials is much more a statistics-based course compared to Reg Affairs, thus, it really surprised me when he adapted to similar teaching styles. As far as I know, people would rather learning the materials at home than attending his lectures to hear all those stories. He did not interpret the materials in a comprehensive way, leaving us so confused about all those equations and calculations.

strengths: 
-the professor is very knowledgeable about the material and shares insight about various stakeholders within the regulatory affairs field
-he encourages questions and answers them to the best of his knowledge 

weaknesses:
-occasionally hard to reach the professor outside of classroom setting via emails or office hours
Very knowledgeable about the work and quite laid back
Great professor with great experience with great connections, and with great stories.

Dr. Makuch has a wealth of interesting stories to punctuate and highlight course topics, and is a cordial and enjoyable lecturer. If anything I would have liked him to take more time in emphasizing and reviewing the key biostatistical methods and other topics of primary importance during lectures, rather than share another entertaining story.
The instructor is interesting.
Nice.

Professor Makuch is very experienced  in clinical trials, and he does a good job explaining the concepts and methods to approach problems in clinical trials. His review sessions going through homework questions before exams are very helpful. Professor Makuch also trusts students by making the final exam online, allowing everyone to be flexible about the final exam schedule.

The instructor gives us reading and slides, but sometimes neither of these two help to finish homework. And there are mistakes on the solution of homework. Even the instructor noticed the mistake, he did not correct it and update a new version.
Professor Makuch has great slides and gives good lectures. He is also very knowledgeable.
the same, too casual
He clearly knows a lot, but just doesn't know how to teach the material. One time I went to his office hours and he was not there like he said he would be.
Professor Makuch is a kind and patient professor but his classes are sometimes boring.

Professor Makuch is very informative and he is good at sharing his experience. Sometimes not very focused on the slides though. I like the idea of inviting guest speakers from the industry to share their knowledge in class.
The instructor is really patient.

Professor Makuch has a lot of experience in this area, and indeed an expert in this area. He shares us many insights into this industry, the right things, and the opposite. But one thing is, we are here to learn something basic, so we really hope that he could spend more time explaining basic concepts and set a feedback system during our class.
A very nice professor
strength: very approachable
has great stories about working in industry, is engaging with students and picks informative guest lecturers
Professor Makuch is a extremely knowledgable and approachable person. I feel that Professor Makuch does better with smaller class-sizes.

It's for sure that Dr. Makuch is a very well-known, experienced expert in his field. But his style was, disorganized if I want to summarize with a word. I am not sure he was caring the students or not, because sometimes he seemed like he was really paying attention to us but another day, his style was very careless. It was good to listen stories about his experiences but it was occupying most the the class hour sometimes, and left a little for the main topic. The homeworks were containing mistakes (even the solutions) and when we went to tell those to him, he was like "ah, there is a mistake there" but he was not informing rest of the class about that.
Professor Makuch is very experienced and therefore has many examples to help us understand the course material.

He would take weeks to answer my emails, he wouldn't show up during his office hours. He would also answer his phone during lecture and then proceeds to explain who he was talking to etc. He was unprofessional and there were times I felt he was too tired to teach.

The instructor shared interesting anecdotes and advice from his experiences with clinical trials. Overall, he explained concepts fairly well and was understandable. He made himself available to reach out to and was responsive to students. However, he did have a tendency to go on tangents and thus was unable to finish some lectures in time, even though the concepts would be on the midterm/ final. Possibly, making sure to cover important concepts within the time limit should be prioritized, and allow time for interesting questions and discussion also.

Terrible teacher. His lectures were incomprehensible, disorganized, and often overtly bigotly (calling a colleague of color with a skin disorder "Spot, like a dog" and disabled participants "decrepit"). When I did go to lecture I regretted it and left early.
I think his response to my email is not very quick.
Dr. Makuch is very knowledgeable and an engaging instructor.

I learned little from attending the lectures as the instructor's teaching did not expand on the topics being discussed. During many of the lectures, the instructor provided background to the concept that did not contribute to my understanding of the topic or ability to apply it. There were some lectures that did not pertain to the class concepts and did not help with my understanding of clinical trials.

Cares a lot for students and was very reasonable/fair throughout the whole semester, but I would have appreciated if more effort were placed into preparing the lecture slides or actually having a concrete agenda. Lectures seemed very scattered and repetitive and I stopped showing up to class because of this.
Excellent

Dr. Makuch is clearly very good at his work in the pharma industry, but it does not seem as though teaching large classes are his forte. I imagine his teaching style would be better suited to a seminar setting. 
He also didn't seem to care much about the logistics of teaching a large course. He did not even reserve rooms for the final exam so ended up making it a take-home final about a week out from the final.
inspiring, knowledgeable
Dr. Makuch is a giant in the field of clinical trials. He is funny and very kind. His teaching would be improved if he could work more on his slides.
Has delivered the course coherently and as described.
I would not recommend this class to another student. I do not feel like it was a worthwhile class, I didn't really learn much and the style of the course is disorganized and not stimulating.
I would 100% recommend this course to all of my colleagues.
Learnt a lot! And the professor is awesome. Highly recommend!
The course is necessary and we could learn many useful knowledge.
This is a good class if you are trying to understand how clinical trials work and the ins and outs of the real world in clinical trials.
Not recommended
A great way to get introduced to the world of clinical trials. If thats your interest then take it!
Gives a good introduction to clinical trials to somewhat who has absolutely no knowledge of them. However, someone who has intro knowledge to clinical trials will learn little from this course.
good
I will recommend this course!
Do not take. Not worth the time. The course title sounds more interesting than the class.

Workload of the course is very manageable with completion homework once a week. Open note/book tests. Probably not needed for people with a strong background in biostats or someone who is even slightly familiar with clinical trials.
No. It's terrible. Avoid at all costs.
Worth taken
Take it elsewhere if you can.
Bad
I would recommend it to learn very basic info about clinical trials.
It is good to learn about Clinical  Trials, but it is not so good to learn it this way. I am still super confused. I wish I had learn more.
I would recommend the course as a foundational course to understand the basics of clinical trials though if you want to delve deeper this may not be suitable. it is an introductory course.
A laid back course, covers the basics

This is a good introductory course on clinical trial design and analysis. You get a taste of high level concerns as well as more granular issues in statistical analyses. Dr. Makuch is an engaging instructor. Perhaps it isn't the most hardcore, challenging course on clinical trials you'll ever take but I would say it is a worthwhile for the content covered and the instructor's professional experience.
I would recommend the course to a fellow student.
This course offers a nice introduction to clinical trials and I recommend it to other students.
Not sure. The contents of this course overlap with many other courses. It may not much useful for a biostatistic major student.

This course introduced me into clinical trials and I learned about the importance of having clinical trials and what are the protocols in each stage. I would recommend it to other student because it is helpful.
Great.
This is probably one of the worst courses ive enrolled in at YSPH. I would not recommend it until a considerable amount of structural changes are made to the overall course.
no
it is a low-workload class
Yes I will recommend. Very practical course.
I would recommend this course since it can help you build up more basic knowledge about clinical trials.
This course is important, but how well you learn it may mainly depend on yourself.
A useful class

Yes.

The knowledge is very useful

great class if you're planning to go into industry after graduation. very applicable to twists and turns of real-life situations when conducting clinical trials. is also not too heavy on statistical theory, for the non-mathematically inclined.

If you are interested in clinical trials or regulatory work this is a helpful class, at the very least. Still, I would not rely on this class to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of these fields. It would behoove you to speak with Prof. Makuch to see about possible internships/research work outside of the classroom as a supplement.
I am not sure about recommending that course. I cannot say that I didn't learn anything but I am not sure if it worths the time a student spends.
It is a good course to take and doesn't have too much work load.

The anecdotes and stories from experience were a highlight of the course. Also, it did provide an overview of the process and components of conducting, evaluating, and planning clinical trials. The course could be improved, including the size of the class and making sure to cover and emphasize important concepts within the course time. I would recommend this course for those interested in getting an overview of clinical trials.

This class was absolutely horrible. Prof. Makuch's lectures were incoherent and disorganized. The homework did not help me learn the material. The textbook was dense and boring. There was no rigor in explaining why we used certain statistical tests. I really wanted to learn about clinical trials but I truly do not feel I learned much about that from this class. The class was so poor it made me question if YSPH was worth it.
Would recommend to anyone with an interest in clinical trials

This course summarizes statistical and conceptual topics in clinical trials but largely involves teaching yourself concepts from the lecture slides and asking questions of the TF in preparation of the exams, which were written in a confusing manner but approachable.
Poor

OK-- very easy way to fulfill the BIS elective but I wish that the course was more structured and rigorous. HWs were posted at times two days before they were due and only graded on completion, where some of the solutions were often incorrect. The lectures were not structured whatsoever and the exams were riddled with sometimes ambiguous True/False questions. I don't know if I am leaving the course with as strong of a background in clinical trials as I had hoped, but Prof Makuch is so sweet and does genuinely care about students.

I absolutely would not recommend this course. You're better off taking the Fundamentals of Clinical Trials course online on edX or something. The professor just doesn't seem to care about the course and eventually lecture attendance dipped. Although it is extremely easy to not do any of the work or come to lectures and still figure out the homework assignments and exams, it's just not worth it.

clinical trials design and sample size estimation, 
yes, good foundation in learning clinical trials procedures
The instructor is nice and doesn't want to give students a hard time. If you are interested in clinical trials then you could try.
